Award.AwardTitle: Genetic Ancestry, Race, and Health Disparities: A Biocultural Approach

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Race and human disease are two issues in which genetics and culture play critical and inextricably linked roles. Moreover, research on racial disparities in complex disease is a central focus of the current debate on human genetic variation. This project will investigate the genetic underpinnings of race and disease within a biocultural context. The question driving the research is why African Americans suffer an increased prevalence of hypertension. This is a key test case since people of the African Diaspora suffer disproportionately from a number of complex diseases, which some researchers attribute to a fundamental genetic commonality. However, this view is problematic because of difficulties in defining racial groups and because it minimizes environmental influences on complex disease. This project adds a genetic component to ongoing research to test social and cultural factors involved in hypertension and stress-related phenotypes in African-Americans. DNA samples will be collected from 350 African American individuals and those samples will be assayed for ancestry informative genetic markers (for an estimate of genetic ancestry) and for candidate genes involved in hypertension and related phenotypes. Three sets of questions will be addressed: 1) What are the associations between different measures of race? 2) What association exists between genetic ancestry and hypertension? 3) Are associations between candidate gene polymorphisms and hypertension modified when ancestry, measures of skin color, and novel sociocultural data, such as personal social networks, are added to the model?

The proposed research is a unique biocultural investigation of race and human disease in which the genetic and cultural components are addressed with equal rigor. Racial inequalities in health are among the most hotly debated issues in science. Often the debate is framed in terms of an opposition between genetic and sociocultural factors, when it is more realistic to posit that that there are complex interactions between genetic and sociocultural factors. However, few studies are able to test the independent contributions of genetic and sociocultural factors because ?race? is often used uncritically as a proxy for unspecified genetic, physiologic, behavioral, or sociocultural factors. Thus, this research has the potential to dramatically transform the ways in which we think of race, self-identity and health, and the ways in which we study these phenomena.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of our project was to combine cutting-edge genetic and sociocultural data to test if the combined data enabled us to better identify causes of complex diseases, in this case hypertension in African Americans living in Tallahassee, FL. A biocultural approach makes sense since complex diseases are caused by multiple genetic and environmental factors. However, most studies are designed to investigate only one aspect (genetic or environmental) of the causative factors. Since the field of anthropology is intrinsically interdisciplinary, our biocultural study takes a classic anthropological approach. Our study looks particularly at the effects of racial discrimination, in combination with genetic markers, on blood pressure.

We studied over 30,000 genetic markers, and developed new measures of discrimination, in order to develop a comprehensive picture of the factors that drive changes in blood pressure. We found that a novel measure of unfair treatment experienced by individuals close to the study participant was associated with blood pressure. In particular, the effect of unfair treatment to others on blood pressure varied according to which genotype an individual carried at the angiotensin converting enzyme gene (called ACE) (see Figure).

Our data show that genetic and sociocultural data interact to influence blood pressure, a result that would not have been identified without a biocultural approach that combines both types of data. Furthermore, we see that the effect of unfair treatment to others begins at exposure levels of 3 or higher, suggesting that there is a threshold effect of discrimination before effects on physical and biological health are observed. This cumulative effect of stressors, like racial discrimination, could be a contributing factor in racial heath disparities, which was also a focus of our study.


Last Modified: 07/07/2015
Modified by: Connie J Mulligan

Image
  • The effect of UnfairTreatment_Others on systolic blood pressure varies by ACE Alu genotype, which is a classic Gene x Environment interaction. The G x E effect is novel in this case since unfair treatment to others is a newly developed measure to capture multiple aspects of discrimination.
    Jacklyn Quinlan, Alexis Boulter
    Copyrighted
    Connie J Mulligan
    Genotype and UnfairTreatment_Other interaction with systolic blood pressure
